wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup 4/17/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

40 Organizations Leading the World in Employee Engagement

This week, Gallup recognized 40 leading organizations as part of their annual Great Workplace Award. To qualify, the organizations average nine engaged employees for every one actively disengaged employee, which is more than five times the rate in the U.S. and more than 16 times the rate for workforces worldwide. Among the winners were Adena Health System, Charles Schwab, and Mars, Incorporated.

The secrets to habit change

Changing behavior seems to be the upcoming hot topic, and social scientists are suggesting a few key steps to ensure success: pre-contemplation (thinking through the pros and cons of the current situation), contemplation (rethinking personal beliefs and capabilities), and preparation (crafting a plan to avoid the current problem in the future). In addition to reflection, setting goals and social support is critical to long-term change.

Etsy I.P.O. Tests Pledge to Balance Social Mission and Profit

Etsy has debuted on the Nasdaq stock market and is setting a trend for B Corps public companies. Under this title, they have pledged to adhere to social and environmental accountability guidelines set by a nonprofit organization called B Lab. Our favorite quote from Chad Dickerson, chief executive of Etsy: The success of our business model is based on the success of our sellers. That means we don’t have to make a choice between people and profit.

A Looming Employee Engagement Crisis [INFOGRAPHIC]

Realized Worth has put together a Buzz-Feed-style list to illustrate the correlation between corporate volunteering and engagement at work. Our favorite stat: 94% of employee volunteers believed volunteerism was a core component or positive influence on job satisfaction.

5 hallmarks of successful corporate wellness programs

According to researchers at UNC Chapel Hill, only 7% of companies surveyed in a national 2008 study offer a comprehensive wellness program. The researchers identified five best practices that define a wellness program that’s likely to produce results that benefit employees and employers. The top two include: 1) Programs Are Practical & Accessible 2) The Work Environment Is Health-Conscious.
